content.description: The steepest line in the cave. Heads up on the right side of the cave and heads out a steep roof with the crux pulling over the top.
content.location: Right side of the Rainy Day Cave. Up the steepest part of the wall.

content.description: Climb offers a variety of moves packed into a short 2 bolt climb.Stemming, thin holds, and steep jugs.  Shared anchor with Chinese water torture.
content.location: Right of the two micro climbs in the back of the cave.

content.description: Continuous long pulls between good holds. Crux is pulling onto the slabby section midway where the holds shrink for a few moves.
content.location: Middle of the right wall outside the main part of the cave. Starts on the belay pad just above where the slope drops away.

content.description: Starts on the same belay pad as Rain Man and climbs up and right to join Horizon Air for its slab/corner crux and arete finish.
content.location: On the right wall. Starts on the belay pad below the tree. Starts in the same place as Rain Man.

content.description: Balancy (bottom), pumpy (top), and funky (all of it) climb on the right side of the cave.
content.protection: 4 bolts. Chain anchor. Be careful making the second clip!
content.location: Right side of the cave. Next to Welcome to Oregon.

content.description: Make some sustained moves up the arete then pull onto the hanging slab into a corner without much to hold onto. Move back right and to the top of the cliff.
content.location: Farthest right (and longest) route on the right wall.

content.description: A cool arete climb on white rock just outside of the cave. Pockets and edges and not-so-obvious holds with a steep finish.
content.location: Just outside the cave on the left.

content.description: Short climb (even for this wall) with a fun crux sequence at the second bolt. Easier climbing takes you to an anchor below the top of the wall.
content.location: Just outside the main part of the cave on the right wall. Starts between the tree and the wall.

content.description: One of two two-bolt micro climbs in the back of the cave (the left one). Fun, steep climbing on big holds. Add some value (in that contrived sport-climber way) by doing a sit start traverse in from the right. Watch out for bat/bird/critter poop near the top.
content.protection: Two bolts. This route shares chains with its conjoined twin: "Rain Sucks" (10a, slab/corner).
content.location: The leftmost of two climbs in the very back of the cave.

content.description: Rainy Day Cave is somewhat of a misnomer. It's not really a cave by the strictest of definitions and is therefore not that great for climbing on the rainiest of days. Nevertheless, the cave offers some cool steep sport climbs that are generally pretty short with the longest routes on the outside of the cave proper.
